properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A trough of low pressure will push across the BC Interior tonight. Moisture associated with the trough is generating snow at times heavy over the Williston region and the Pine Pass. A further 10 to 15 cm of snowfall accumulations are expected before the snow eases early on Thursday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T14:54:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T23:56:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3523073444.2020
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Moderate northeast winds of 40 km/h gusting to 60 over the Dempster region will persist tonight and then ease early on Thursday morning. The wind combined with loose snow will occasionally reduce visibility to 800 metres or less. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T14:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T00:02:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3048620504.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of fine particulates are expected and will result in poor air quality. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist through Thursday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-12-17T20:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-12-17T03:54:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3416569405.2020
Area: Falardeau - Mont-Valin area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Ville de Saguenay area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A frontal system moving across Vancouver Island is producing strong southeasterly winds of 70 km/h near the water of the Greater Victoria area. The southeast winds will ease this evening but westerly winds of 50 to 70 km/h are forecast to develop overnight as the system passes. Winds will ease below warning criteria Thursday morning but it will be breezy the remainder of the day. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T15:50:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T23:50:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0958011263.2020
Area: Greater Victoria
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. A strong Pacific frontal system will move across southern British Columbia tonight and tomorrow. Light snow over Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass will become heavier tonight and will persist into Thursday afternoon. Accumulations of up to 15 cm of snow can be expected tonight and another 5 to 10 cm is forecast for Thursday before easing off late Thursday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T15:04:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T23:04:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0876341431.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall on Thursday night. Locations: northern Nova Scotia Time span: beginning Thursday afternoon and ending Friday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin late in the day on Thursday, with deteriorating conditions throughout the evening and into the night. Heaviest snowfall rates are expected overnight. Current indications are that there is the potential for accumulations possibly reaching 15 cm by Friday morning. As with most storms that pass south of Nova Scotia, a small difference in the forecast track could result in a significant change in the snowfall forecast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T17:51:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T01:51:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0721565726.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A low pressure tracking across the northern Prairies will spread heavy snow into northern Manitoba beginning Thursday afternoon. The heaviest snow will fall on Thursday night before tapering off late Friday. In addition to the heavy snow, gusty northerly winds up to 70 km/h will develop in the wake of this system. At Churchill, blizzard or near blizzard conditions may develop on Friday as the low deepens over Hudson Bay. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T13:23:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T21:23:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3617662046.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries, snowsqualls, and blowing snow are expected to ease tonight. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: this evening. Remarks: snowfall rates will begin to diminish tonight as the winds begin to ease. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T05:59:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T19:54:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3764442128.2020
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds combined with snow will generate blizzard conditions over these regions beginning overnight tonight. Weather conditions will improve Thursday evening. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T19:33:26-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic airmass combined with some moderate winds will generate wind chill values between - 38 and - 40 overnight tonight and Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T18:29:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T03:14:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1442002467.2020

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight and early Thursday morning. A narrow band of lake effect snow is expected to develop over western Lake Ontario this evening. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible before the snow tapers off early Thursday morning. Under the lake effect bands heavy bursts of snow and blowing snow can significantly reduce visibilities. Motorists are advised to exercise caution and be prepared for quickly changing driving conditions. Consider postponing non essential travel as snow covered and icy roads are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T16:59:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T03:08:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3250530439.2020
Area: City of Hamilton, Mississauga - Brampton, Halton Hills - Milton, Burlington - Oakville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures or windchill values near minus 50 will continue until the overnight when approaching cloud cover will allow temperatures to warm somewhat. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, blowing snow and strong winds are occurring. Additional snowfall tonight: 5 cm, except 10 cm over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 60 km/h. Locations: Bay of Islands to Hawke's Bay. Time span: ending overnight tonight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected on Thursday. Total snowfall: 15-25 cm, with higher amounts possible inland. Locations: southern mainland Nova Scotia. Time span: beginning Thursday morning in southwestern Nova Scotia and progressing north and east throughout the day, then tapering to flurries Friday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin early in the day on Thursday, with deteriorating conditions throughout the afternoon and evening. Heaviest snowfall rates are expected Thursday evening and into Thursday night. Current indications are that there is the potential for accumulations of 15 to 25 cm to occur over portions of mainland Nova Scotia by Friday morning, with the highest amount expected over inland areas. ### There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T17:51:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T01:51:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3922341913.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Heavy snow will continue until Thursday afternoon. The snowfall warning may need to be expanded to the south to Grande Prairie if the system tracks farther south than forecast. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T20:46:35-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are occurring. Further snowfall expected: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 70 km/h. Locations: Hopedale to Makkovik. Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow and strong northwesterly winds are combining with fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve overnight tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-17T11:29:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T02:26:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3829805715.2020
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels are expected. Locations: east and northeast coasts, between St. John's and La Scie. Time span: tonight and Thursday morning. Remarks: Higher than normal water levels are likely during high tide this evening and possibly again Thursday morning due to a combination of high waves and pounding surf. Minor coastal flooding or erosion may occur. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-17T16:59:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T02:22:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3536359982.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall expected: 5 to 10 cm except 15 inland and over higher terrain. Locations: Cartwright and vicinity. Time span: continuing until Thursday morning. Remarks: Snow will continue tonight, combined with winds up to 80 km/h and areas of blowing snow. The snow will taper off or end over all areas by early Thursday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-17T10:59:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-17T02:27:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0582671084.2020
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic airmass combined with some moderate winds will generate wind chill values between - 38 and - 40 tonight into Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T08:30:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-16T16:31:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4165003265.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 55 will continue tonight. Temperatures will warm up on Thursday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-17T19:59:00-00:00

Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
